overview: Your Committee finds that Hawaii is the only state that does not maintain a list of practicing pharmacy technicians, leaving a significant gap in oversight that can impact patient safety. [14] This measure provides the regulatory oversight needed to ensure that these essential health care workers have the appropriate background and supervision, while also facilitating access to training opportunities and expanding their scope of practice through additional certifications. [14] This measure builds upon Act 104 that allows, in part, pharmacists, pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns the ability to administer immunizations and vaccinations to persons three years and older under the direct supervision of a pharmacist. [13]
assumptions_and_methodology: Testimony states this initiative comes at a reasonable cost and represents a prudent investment in ensuring the safety, efficiency, and adaptability of our pharmacy workforce. [13] Testimony also suggests that the measure is a prudent investment in the safety, efficiency, and adaptability of our pharmacy workforce into the future. [13]
agency_impact: The Board of Pharmacy recently formed a permitted interaction group to look at the best methods to regulate pharmacy technicians for quality and general assurance. [13] The Board agreed that a registration for all technicians may be a prudent initial step regarding the regulation of pharmacy technicians. [13] The creation of a pharmacy technician data repository is an essential step forward, providing a centralized resource for communicating practice and regulatory changes. [13]
economic_impact: The registration of pharmacy technicians is warranted and appropriate for the level of responsibility and trust afforded by the public. [13] This measure supports public health and safety by ensuring that these essential health care workers have the appropriate background and supervision. [13] Regulation will allow Hawai‘i to adapt to changes and avoid falling behind in providing the best possible care to our communities. [13]
policy_impact: This measure builds upon Act 104 to require that pharmacy technicians are registered by the state. [13] This measure is exempt from the requirements of a sunrise analysis due to the exigent need for technician regulation. [13] The Board of Pharmacy supports an expansion to the scope of practice for nationally certified technicians, including allowances provided in Act 104 of the 2024 legislative session. [13]
six_year_fiscal_implications: This initiative comes at a reasonable cost and represents a prudent investment in ensuring the safety, efficiency, and adaptability of our pharmacy workforce. [13] The registration of pharmacy technicians is important for protecting patient safety because pharmacy technicians are essential team members who are critical to the workflow of a pharmacy. [13] Currently, there is no requirement for reporting violations, so violators can easily move from one pharmacy to another. [13] This bill will require the pharmacist in charge to report violations conducted by registered technicians. [13]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: New testimony and committee reports emphasize that Hawaiʻi is the only state that does not maintain a list of practicing pharmacy technicians, which creates a significant gap in oversight that can impact patient safety. [13] The measure is now explicitly linked to and builds upon Act 104 of the 2024 legislative session, which expanded the roles of pharmacy technicians to include administering immunizations. [13] The Board of Pharmacy's support is further detailed, noting the formation of a permitted interaction group which concluded that registration is a prudent initial step. [13] Testimony highlights the creation of a pharmacy technician data repository as an essential tool for communicating practice changes. [13] The measure is noted to be exempt from the requirements of a sunrise analysis due to the exigent need for technician regulation. [13] Multiple testimonies characterize the initiative as a 'reasonable cost' and a 'prudent investment'. [13]
